OpenAI Says It's Scanning Users' ChatGPT Conversations and Reporting Content to the PoliceNoor Al-Sibai11/25/2025

OpenAI has authorized itself to call law enforcement if users say threatening enough things when talking to ChatGPT.

	<script type="application/ld+json" class="yoast-schema-graph">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"NewsArticle","@id":"https://futurism.com/openai-scanning-conversations-police#article","isPartOf":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/openai-scanning-conversations-police"},"author":[{"@type":"Person","@id":"https://futurism.com#/schema/person/609f8fa9105512cc15729cf5b7f3fc29","name":"Noor Al-Sibai","description":"At Futurism, I've often been drawn to unpacking the narratives that underlie technological, scientific and medical progress, with a special interest in areas of conflict and ambiguity that end up setting agendas and steering the fates of both elites and the hoi polloi. I'm a committed generalist, but I often find myself returning to work involving NASA and the private space sector, the effects of AI on media and society, and the mechanics of the pharmaceutical industry, with a specific focus on the spread of GLP-1 drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy.\r\n\r\nPrior to Futurism, I worked for publications ranging from Media Matters and Truthdig to Raw Story and Bustle. I'm also the author of \"Myspace Scene Queens,\" a 2024 title in Instar Books' acclaimed \"Remember the Internet\" series. My work at Futurism has been cited by outlets including the New Yorker, Slate, Nieman Lab, the Verge, the MIT Technology Review, the Sunday Times, and the Daily Beast.\r\n\r\nI grew up in North Carolina, attended the University of North Carolina at Asheville, and now live in Brooklyn, New York. In my free time, I'm an avid reader and music fan; you can probably find me at a local poetry reading, concert, underground rave, or DJ set. I'm the proud parent of an ineffable orange cat named Mee-Mow.","url":"https://futurism.com/authors/nooralsibai","image":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/avatar_user_151823_1741024562.jpg?quality=85","sameAs":["https://bsky.app/profile/noorfromfuturism.bsky.social"]}],"headline":"OpenAI Says It’s Scanning Users’ ChatGPT Conversations and Reporting Content to the Police","datePublished":"2025-08-27T17:05:11-04:00","mainEntityOfPage":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/openai-scanning-conversations-police"},"wordCount":777,"commentCount":0,"publisher":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/#organization"},"image":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/openai-scanning-conversations-police#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?quality=85","keywords":["chatgpt","OpenAI","police","privacy"],"articleSection":["Artificial Intelligence","OpenAI"],"inLanguage":"en-US","potentialAction":[{"@type":"CommentAction","name":"Comment","target":["https://futurism.com/openai-scanning-conversations-police#respond"]}],"dateModified":"2025-08-27T17:05:11-04:00","ArticleBody":"Update: It looks like this may have been OpenAI's attempt to get ahead of a horrifying story that just broke, about a man who fell into AI psychosis and killed his mother in a murder-suicide. Full details here.\n\n\n\nFor the better part of a year, we've watched — and reported — in horror as more and more stories emerge about AI chatbots leading people to self-harm, delusions, hospitalization, arrest, and suicide.\n\n\n\nAs the loved ones of the people impacted by these dangerous bots rally for change to prevent such harm from happening to anyone else, the companies that run these AIs have been slow to implement safeguards — and OpenAI, whose ChatGPT has been repeatedly implicated in what experts are now calling \"AI psychosis,\" has until recently done little more than offer copy-pasted promises.\n\n\n\nIn a new blog post admitting certain failures amid its users' mental health crises, OpenAI also quietly disclosed that it's now scanning users' messages for certain types of harmful content, escalating particularly worrying content to human staff for review — and, in some cases, reporting it to the cops.\n\n\n\n\"When we detect users who are planning to harm others, we route their conversations to specialized pipelines where they are reviewed by a small team trained on our usage policies and who are authorized to take action, including banning accounts,\" the blog post notes. \"If human reviewers determine that a case involves an imminent threat of serious physical harm to others, we may refer it to law enforcement.\"\n\n\n\nThat short and vague statement leaves a lot to be desired — and OpenAI's usage policies, referenced as the basis on which the human review team operates, don't provide much more clarity.\n\n\n\nWhen describing its rule against \"harm [to] yourself or others,\" the company listed off some pretty standard examples of prohibited activity, including using ChatGPT \"to promote suicide or self-harm, develop or use weapons, injure others or destroy property, or engage in unauthorized activities that violate the security of any service or system.\"\n\n\n\nBut in the post warning users that the company will call the authorities if they seem like they're going to hurt someone, OpenAI also acknowledged that it is \"currently not referring self-harm cases to law enforcement to respect people’s privacy given the uniquely private nature of ChatGPT interactions.\"\n\n\n\nWhile ChatGPT has in the past proven itself pretty susceptible to so-called jailbreaks that trick it into spitting out instructions to build neurotoxins or step-by-step instructions to kill yourself, this new rule adds an additional layer of confusion. It remains unclear which exact types of chats could result in user conversations being flagged for human review, much less getting referred to police. We've reached out to OpenAI to ask for clarity.\n\n\n\nWhile it's certainly a relief that AI conversations won't result in police wellness checks — which often end up causing more harm to the person in crisis due to most cops' complete lack of training in handling mental health situations — it's also kind of bizarre that OpenAI even mentions privacy, given that it admitted in the same post that it's monitoring user chats and potentially sharing them with the fuzz.\n\n\n\nTo make the announcement all the weirder, this new rule seems to contradict the company's pro-privacy stance amid its ongoing lawsuit with the New York Times and other publishers as they seek access to troves of ChatGPT logs to determine whether any of their copyrighted data had been used to train its models.\n\n\n\nOpenAI has steadfastly rejected the publishers' request on grounds of protecting user privacy and has, more recently, begun trying to limit the amount of user chats it has to give the plaintiffs.\n\n\n\nLast month, the company's CEO Sam Altman admitted during an appearance on a podcast that using ChatGPT as a therapist or attorney doesn't confer the same confidentiality that talking to a flesh-and-blood professional would — and that thanks to the NYT lawsuit, the company may be forced to turn those chats over to courts.\n\n\n\nIn other words, OpenAI is stuck between a rock and a hard place. The PR blowback from its users spiraling into mental health crises and dying by suicide is appalling — but since it's clearly having trouble controlling its own tech enough to protect users from those harmful scenarios, it's falling back on heavy-handed moderation that flies in the face of its own CEO's promises.\n\n\n\nMore on the dark side of ChatGPT: After Their Son's Suicide, His Parents Were Horrified to Find His Conversations With <style id='acf-newsletter-review-style-inline-css'>
.NewsletterReviews-block {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: center;
}

.NewsletterReviews-block .NewsletterReviews-title {
  border-bottom: 1px solid #000;
  display: block;
  font-size: 12px;
  font-weight: 700;
  letter-spacing: 0.01em;
  line-height: 1em;
  padding: 0 5px 10px;
  margin: 0 0 50px;
  text-align: center;
  text-transform: uppercase;
}

.NewsletterReviews-wrapper {
  min-height: 300px;
  overflow: hidden;
  width: 100%;
  transition: height ease .3s;
}

.NewsletterReviews-list {
  align-items: start;
  display: flex;
  transform: translateX(0%);
  transition: all ease .2s;
}

body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block ul.NewsletterReviews-indicators,
body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block ul.NewsletterReviews-list {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block .NewsletterReviews-indicators li,
body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block .NewsletterReviews-list li {
  list-style: none;
}

.NewsletterReview {
  align-items: center;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  margin-right: 30px;
  min-height: 300px;
  min-width: 100%;
  padding: 0;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-content {
  align-items: center;
  background: #fff;
  border-radius: 10px;
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  justify-items: center;
  margin-top: 40px;
  max-width: 540px;
  min-height: 195px;
  padding: 60px 30px 40px;
  position: relative;
  width: 100%;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-content.noPicture {
  margin-top: 0px;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-figure {
  border-radius: 100%;
  height: 80px;
  left: calc(50% - 40px);
  overflow: hidden;
  position: absolute;
  top: -40px;
  width: 80px;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-figure img {
  aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;
  height: 100%;
  width: 100%;
  object-fit: cover;
  object-position: top center;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial {
  padding-bottom: 15px;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial,
.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial * {
  font-size: 35px;
  font-weight: 450;
  letter-spacing: -0.01em;
  line-height: 1em;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-signature {
  font-size: 16px;
  font-weight: 450;
  letter-spacing: -0.01em;
  line-height: 1em;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-signature > p:first-child,
.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial > p:first-child {
  margin-top: 0;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-signature > p:last-child,
.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial > p:last-child {
  margin-bottom: 0;
}

body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block ul.NewsletterReviews-indicators {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  gap: 10px;
  position: relative;
  padding-top: 50px;
}

.NewsletterReviews-indicators li {
  background-color: transparent;
  border: 1px solid #000;
  border-radius: 10px;
  cursor: pointer;
  display: block;
  height: 10px;
  width: 10px;
}

.NewsletterReviews-indicators li.current {
  background-color: #000;
  content: '';
  cursor: inherit;
  left: 0;
  position: absolute;
  transition: left ease .2s;
}

.NewsletterReviews-indicators li.current {
  background-color: #000;
}

@media (max-width: 664px) {
  .NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-content {
    padding: 65px 22px 40px;
  }

  .NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial {
    font-size: 30px;
  }
}

</style>
<style id='recurrent-newsletter-email-style-inline-css'>

.newsletter-signup-form-wrapper {
	position: relative;
}

.newsletter-signup-success {

	position: absolute;

}

<style id='recurrent-top-stories-style-inline-css'>
.recurrent-top-story-block .content-box-title {
	font-weight: 700;
	margin-bottom: 1.25rem;
	text-align: center;
}

.recurrent-top-stories-container {
	display: flex;
	overflow-x: auto;
	grid-template-columns: repeat(3, minmax(0, 1fr));
	gap: 1.5rem;
	margin-bottom: 1rem;
	padding: 0 !important;
}

.recurrent-top-stories-container > li {
	position: relative;
	list-style: none;
	min-width: 280px;
	width: 280px;

	.card-post {
		height: 100%;

		.post-content {
			height: 100%;
    		display: flex;
    		flex-direction: column;

			.card-post-byline {
				margin-top: auto;

				.article-byline .item-wrapper {
					margin-right: 0;
				}
			}
		}
	}
}

.recurrent-top-stories-container > li:not(:last-child)::after {
	content: '';
	position: absolute;
	background-color: #d1d5db;
	right: -0.75rem;
	top: 0;
	bottom: auto;
	left: auto;
	height: 100%;
	width: 1px;
}

.recurrent-top-story-block .post-tax-badges .sponsored-badge {
	margin: 0 auto;
}

@media (min-width: 1024px) {
	.recurrent-top-stories-container {
		display: grid;
		gap: 1.75rem;
	}

	.recurrent-top-stories-container > li {
		min-width: 0;
		width: auto;
	}

	.recurrent-top-stories-container > li:not(:last-child)::after {
		right: -0.875rem;
	}

	.recurrent-top-story-block .content-box-title {
		margin-bottom: 2rem;
	}
}

</style>

			<h1 class="article-title">OpenAI Says It’s Scanning Users’ ChatGPT Conversations and Reporting Content to the Police</h1>

	<div class="article-layout-wrapper w-full flex flex-col lg:flex-row gap-5 max-w-full ">

									<section class="entry-content pw-content-edge-targeting" data-module="TableOfContents">
	<div>
			<figure class="article-featured-image-figure">
			<div class="relative ">
	<img
		class="archive-post-thumb article-featured-image w-full h-auto mb-3"

					src="https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?quality=85&w=1152"
		
					srcset="https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=280&h=147 280w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=289&h=152 289w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=300&h=157 300w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=308&h=162 308w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=370&h=194 370w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=412&h=216 412w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=580&h=304 580w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=660&h=346 660w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=704&h=370 704w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=762&h=400 762w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=768&h=403 768w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=1024&h=538 1024w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/openai-scanning-conversations-police.jpg?w=1152&h=605 1152w"
		
					sizes="(max-width: 1152px) 100vw, 1152px"
		
		
					fetchpriority="high"
		
					width="2048"
		
					height="1075"
		
		alt="OpenAI has authorized itself to call law enforcement if users say threatening enough things when talking to ChatGPT."
	/>

	</div>
			
	<div class="article-featured-image-caption-container">
		<figcaption class="article-featured-image-caption">
			 <em>Image: Getty / Futurism</em>		</figcaption>
	</div>
		</figure>
	
	
	
	
	
	<div class="content-wrapper">
		
<p class="pw-incontent-excluded article-paragraph skip"><em>Update: It looks like this may have been OpenAI’s attempt to get ahead of a horrifying story that just broke, about a man who fell into AI psychosis and killed his mother in a murder-suicide. <a href="https://futurism.com/man-chatgpt-psychosis-murders-mother">Full details here</a>.</em></p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">For the <a href="https://futurism.com/the-byte/ai-chatbot-urged-teen-suicide">better part of a year</a>, we’ve watched — <a href="https://futurism.com/chatgpt-mental-health-crises">and reported</a> — in horror as more and more stories emerge about AI chatbots leading people to <a href="https://futurism.com/ai-chatbots-teens-self-harm">self-harm</a>, <a href="https://futurism.com/chatgpt-mental-health-crises">delusions</a>, <a href="https://futurism.com/chatgpt-man-hospital">hospitalization</a>, <a href="https://futurism.com/commitment-jail-chatgpt-psychosis">arrest</a>, and <a href="https://futurism.com/woman-suicide-openai-therapist">suicide</a>.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">As the loved ones of the people impacted by these dangerous bots <a href="https://futurism.com/mother-teen-suicide-chatbots-letter">rally for change</a> to prevent such harm from happening to anyone else, the <a href="https://futurism.com/character-ai-parental-controls-bypass">companies that run</a> these AIs have been slow to implement safeguards — and OpenAI, whose ChatGPT has been repeatedly implicated in what experts are now calling “<a href="https://futurism.com/paper-ai-psychosis-schizophrenia">AI psychosis</a>,” has until recently done little more than offer <a href="https://futurism.com/openai-response-chatgpt-mental-health">copy-pasted promises</a>.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">In a <a href="https://openai.com/index/helping-people-when-they-need-it-most/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">new blog post</a> admitting certain failures amid its users’ mental health crises, OpenAI also quietly disclosed that it’s now scanning users’ messages for certain types of harmful content, escalating particularly worrying content to human staff for review — and, in some cases, reporting it to the cops.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">“When we detect users who are planning to harm others, we route their conversations to specialized pipelines where they are reviewed by a small team trained on our usage policies and who are authorized to take action, including banning accounts,” the blog post notes. “If human reviewers determine that a case involves an imminent threat of serious physical harm to others, we may refer it to law enforcement.”</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">That short and vague statement leaves a lot to be desired — and <a href="https://openai.com/policies/usage-policies/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">OpenAI’s usage policies</a>, referenced as the basis on which the human review team operates, don’t provide much more clarity.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">When describing its rule against “harm [to] yourself or others,” the company listed off some pretty standard examples of prohibited activity, including using ChatGPT “to promote suicide or self-harm, develop or use weapons, injure others or destroy property, or engage in unauthorized activities that violate the security of any service or system.”</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">But in the post warning users that the company will call the authorities if they seem like they’re going to hurt someone, OpenAI also acknowledged that it is “currently not referring self-harm cases to law enforcement to respect people’s privacy given the uniquely private nature of ChatGPT interactions.”</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">While ChatGPT has in the past proven itself pretty susceptible to so-called jailbreaks that trick it into spitting out <a href="https://openai.com/policies/usage-policies/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">instructions to build neurotoxins</a> or step-by-step <a href="https://news.northeastern.edu/2025/07/31/chatgpt-suicide-research/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">instructions to kill yourself</a>, this new rule adds an additional layer of confusion. It remains unclear which exact types of chats could result in user conversations being flagged for human review, much less getting referred to police. We’ve reached out to OpenAI to ask for clarity.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">While it’s certainly a relief that AI conversations won’t result in police wellness checks — which <a href="https://www.safetyreimagined.org/papers/welfare-checks" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">often end up causing more harm</a> to the person in crisis due to most cops’ complete lack of training in handling mental health situations<strong> </strong>— it’s also kind of bizarre that OpenAI even mentions privacy, given that it admitted in the same post that it’s monitoring user chats and potentially sharing them with the fuzz.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">To make the announcement all the weirder, this new rule seems to contradict the company’s pro-privacy stance amid its <a href="https://futurism.com/openai-content-new-york-times-lawsuit">ongoing lawsuit</a> with the <em>New York Times</em> and other publishers as they seek access to <a href="https://futurism.com/newspaper-chatgpt-logs-lawsuit">troves of ChatGPT logs</a> to determine whether any of their copyrighted data had been used to train its models.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">OpenAI has <a href="https://openai.com/index/response-to-nyt-data-demands/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">steadfastly rejected</a> the publishers’ request on grounds of protecting user privacy and has, more recently, begun trying to <a href="https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2025/08/openai-offers-20-million-user-chats-in-chatgpt-lawsuit-nyt-wants-120-million/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">limit the amount</a> of user chats it has to give the plaintiffs.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">Last month, the company’s CEO <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2025/07/25/sam-altman-warns-theres-no-legal-confidentiality-when-using-chatgpt-as-a-therapist/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Sam Altman admitted</a> during an appearance on a podcast that using ChatGPT as a therapist or attorney doesn’t confer the same confidentiality that talking to a flesh-and-blood professional would — and that thanks to the <em>NYT</em> lawsuit, the company may be forced to turn those chats over to courts.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">In other words, OpenAI is stuck between a rock and a hard place. The PR blowback from its users spiraling into mental health crises and dying by suicide is appalling — but since it’s clearly having trouble controlling its own tech enough to protect users from those harmful scenarios, it’s falling back on heavy-handed moderation that flies in the face of its own CEO’s promises.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip"><strong>More on the dark side of ChatGPT: </strong><a href="https://futurism.com/lawsuit-parents-son-suicide-chatgpt"><em>After Their Son’s Suicide, His Parents Were Horrified to Find His Conversations With ChatGPT</em></a></p>
	</div>

readabilityObject.title: OpenAI Says It’s Scanning Users’ ChatGPT Conversations and Reporting Content to the Police
readabilityObject.content:
Update: It looks like this may have been OpenAI’s attempt to get ahead of a horrifying story that just broke, about a man who fell into AI psychosis and killed his mother in a murder-suicide. Full details here.

For the better part of a year, we’ve watched — and reported — in horror as more and more stories emerge about AI chatbots leading people to self-harm, delusions, hospitalization, arrest, and suicide.

As the loved ones of the people impacted by these dangerous bots rally for change to prevent such harm from happening to anyone else, the companies that run these AIs have been slow to implement safeguards — and OpenAI, whose ChatGPT has been repeatedly implicated in what experts are now calling “AI psychosis,” has until recently done little more than offer copy-pasted promises.

In a new blog post admitting certain failures amid its users’ mental health crises, OpenAI also quietly disclosed that it’s now scanning users’ messages for certain types of harmful content, escalating particularly worrying content to human staff for review — and, in some cases, reporting it to the cops.

“When we detect users who are planning to harm others, we route their conversations to specialized pipelines where they are reviewed by a small team trained on our usage policies and who are authorized to take action, including banning accounts,” the blog post notes. “If human reviewers determine that a case involves an imminent threat of serious physical harm to others, we may refer it to law enforcement.”

That short and vague statement leaves a lot to be desired — and OpenAI’s usage policies, referenced as the basis on which the human review team operates, don’t provide much more clarity.

When describing its rule against “harm [to] yourself or others,” the company listed off some pretty standard examples of prohibited activity, including using ChatGPT “to promote suicide or self-harm, develop or use weapons, injure others or destroy property, or engage in unauthorized activities that violate the security of any service or system.”

But in the post warning users that the company will call the authorities if they seem like they’re going to hurt someone, OpenAI also acknowledged that it is “currently not referring self-harm cases to law enforcement to respect people’s privacy given the uniquely private nature of ChatGPT interactions.”

While ChatGPT has in the past proven itself pretty susceptible to so-called jailbreaks that trick it into spitting out instructions to build neurotoxins or step-by-step instructions to kill yourself, this new rule adds an additional layer of confusion. It remains unclear which exact types of chats could result in user conversations being flagged for human review, much less getting referred to police. We’ve reached out to OpenAI to ask for clarity.

While it’s certainly a relief that AI conversations won’t result in police wellness checks — which often end up causing more harm to the person in crisis due to most cops’ complete lack of training in handling mental health situations — it’s also kind of bizarre that OpenAI even mentions privacy, given that it admitted in the same post that it’s monitoring user chats and potentially sharing them with the fuzz.

To make the announcement all the weirder, this new rule seems to contradict the company’s pro-privacy stance amid its ongoing lawsuit with the New York Times and other publishers as they seek access to troves of ChatGPT logs to determine whether any of their copyrighted data had been used to train its models.

OpenAI has steadfastly rejected the publishers’ request on grounds of protecting user privacy and has, more recently, begun trying to limit the amount of user chats it has to give the plaintiffs.

Last month, the company’s CEO Sam Altman admitted during an appearance on a podcast that using ChatGPT as a therapist or attorney doesn’t confer the same confidentiality that talking to a flesh-and-blood professional would — and that thanks to the NYT lawsuit, the company may be forced to turn those chats over to courts.

In other words, OpenAI is stuck between a rock and a hard place. The PR blowback from its users spiraling into mental health crises and dying by suicide is appalling — but since it’s clearly having trouble controlling its own tech enough to protect users from those harmful scenarios, it’s falling back on heavy-handed moderation that flies in the face of its own CEO’s promises.

More on the dark side of ChatGPT: After Their Son’s Suicide, His Parents Were Horrified to Find His Conversations With ChatGPT

author.name: Noor Al-Sibai
author.description:
At Futurism, I've often been drawn to unpacking the narratives that underlie technological, scientific and medical progress, with a special interest in areas of conflict and ambiguity that end up setting agendas and steering the fates of both elites and the hoi polloi. I'm a committed generalist, but I often find myself returning to work involving NASA and the private space sector, the effects of AI on media and society, and the mechanics of the pharmaceutical industry, with a specific focus on the spread of GLP-1 drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy.

Prior to Futurism, I worked for publications ranging from Media Matters and Truthdig to Raw Story and Bustle. I'm also the author of "Myspace Scene Queens," a 2024 title in Instar Books' acclaimed "Remember the Internet" series. My work at Futurism has been cited by outlets including the New Yorker, Slate, Nieman Lab, the Verge, the MIT Technology Review, the Sunday Times, and the Daily Beast.

I grew up in North Carolina, attended the University of North Carolina at Asheville, and now live in Brooklyn, New York. In my free time, I'm an avid reader and music fan; you can probably find me at a local poetry reading, concert, underground rave, or DJ set. I'm the proud parent of an ineffable orange cat named Mee-Mow.
